mercedestrenzr 0.0.0.9000

    Listing Search

    listing_search.Rd

    Return the top listings that are within the budget specified by the user. The results are filtered by an optional input, model, and sorted by ascending price and another the specified feature in the sort_feature parameter.

    listing_search(
  data,
  budget = c(0, Inf),
  model = "any",
  sort_feature = "odometer_mi",
  ascending = TRUE,
  price_col = "price_USD",
  model_col = "model"
)

    Arguments

    data

    data.frame The input dataframe containing listing and car attributes

    budget

    number or numeric vector of length 2 The maximum budget, or the range of budget when passing a list.

    model

    character The model of the car that the user is interested in. The default is to include listings of any model.

    sort_feature

    character The numeric variable that the user is interested in using to sort the result. The default value is to sort by odometer value.

    ascending

    bool Boolean value that indicate whether the sort is ascending. The default value is True.

    price_col

    character Character value that indicate the column name of price column.

    model_col

    character Character value that indicate the column name of model column.

    Value

    data.frame A data frame of the sorted listings that matches user's expected budget range.

    Examples

    sample_data <- data.frame(condition = c("good", "average", "average", "new"),
price_USD = c(50000, 20000, 80000, 90000),
model = c("s-class", "glk", "gls", "gls"),
odometer_mi = c(12000, 30000, 35000, 150000),
year = c(2016, 2015, 2020, 2010))
listing_search(sample_data, budget=c(0, 30000), model = "any",
sort_feature = "odometer_mi", ascending = TRUE)
#>   price_USD model odometer_mi condition year
#> 1     20000   glk       30000   average 2015
listing_search(sample_data, budget=50000, model = "gls",
sort_feature = "year", ascending = FALSE)
#> [1] price_USD   model       year        condition   odometer_mi
#> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)
